articles.headline: Crisis Past, Obama May Have Missed a Chance
articles.snippet: President Obama and his party face a problem that stems from decisions he made when he took office.
articles.abstract: President Obama and his party face a problem that stems from decisions he made when he took office.

articles.headline: On Clean Energy, China Skirts Rules
articles.snippet: Big government subsidies for clean energy companies, like cheap land and low-interest loans, may be in violation of W.T.O. rules.
articles.abstract: Big government subsidies for clean energy companies, like cheap land and low-interest loans, may be in violation of W.T.O. rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China  Until very recently, Hunan Province was known mainly for lip-searing spicy food, smoggy cities and destitute pig farmers. Mao was born in a village on the outskirts of Changsha, the provincial capital here in south-central China.

articles.headline: In Season 9, iPods Still Get High Ratings
articles.snippet: The 2010 iPod crop includes modest improvements, a risky new design and a home run in the new iPod Touch.
articles.abstract: The 2010 iPod crop includes modest improvements, a risky new design and a home run in the new iPod Touch.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif.  At a special press event today, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, unveiled a new lineup of iPod models, just in time for the holiday season. The diminutive iPod Shuffle still has no screen and is still made of brushed aluminum, but it now has _____ and comes in _____ colors. Apple tinkered with the proportions of the iPod Nano, too, adding _____ and redesigning the _____. The popular iPod Touch also received a makeover; it’s thinner now, and gains new features like a _____ and a _____. All models now offer better battery life and greater storage capacity.

articles.headline: Court Dismisses a Case Asserting Torture by C.I.A.
articles.snippet: A sharply divided appeals court dismissed a lawsuit involving the C.I.A.’s “extraordinary rendition” program.
articles.abstract: A sharply divided appeals court dismissed a lawsuit involving the C.I.A.’s “extraordinary rendition” program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Wednesday ruled that former prisoners of the C.I.A. could not sue over their alleged torture in overseas prisons because such a lawsuit might expose secret government information.

articles.headline: Mixed Results as NATO Drive on Kandahar Begins
articles.snippet: A delayed push has finally begun, but there has been no major let-up in the Taliban’s campaign of terrorism.
articles.abstract: A delayed push has finally begun, but there has been no major let-up in the Taliban’s campaign of terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The white flags of the Taliban no longer fly from neighborhoods in Kandahar City, as they did in some areas only two weeks ago, replaced instead by the red, black and green Afghan colors.

articles.headline: After Fine, Botox Awaits Approval for Migraine
articles.snippet: Allergan will pay $600 million for its marketing tactics while the F.D.A. decides on the drug’s use for migraines.
articles.abstract: Allergan will pay $600 million for its marketing tactics while the F.D.A. decides on the drug’s use for migraines.
articles.lead_paragraph: In public relations, it’s known as “seeding the market” — stirring up excitement for a forthcoming product or application.

articles.headline: Bracing for Cuts, Military Firms Shed Workers
articles.snippet: Tightened spending at the Pentagon is unsettling the defense industry. A quarter of executives at Lockheed Martin jumped at the chance to take a buyout.
articles.abstract: Tightened spending at the Pentagon is unsettling the defense industry. A quarter of executives at Lockheed Martin jumped at the chance to take a buyout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tightened spending at the Pentagon is unsettling the defense industry, with Lockheed Martin announcing Wednesday that one-quarter of its executives had applied for buyouts as the company cut costs.

articles.headline: Falling Rates Aid Debtors, but Hamper Savers
articles.snippet: Those who live off their savings and investments are hit hard by falling interest rates, as corporations borrow cheaply and sit on the cash.
articles.abstract: Those who live off their savings and investments are hit hard by falling interest rates, as corporations borrow cheaply and sit on the cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: Households and corporations alike are refinancing their loans in droves to take advantage of interest rates that seem impossibly cheap. But those same low rates come with a flip side, driving down the income of retirees and others who live off their savings.

articles.headline: Google Unveils Tool to Speed Up Searches
articles.snippet: Google’s change may save users time, but may also affect the many businesses that have been built around placing search ads on the site.
articles.abstract: Google’s change may save users time, but may also affect the many businesses that have been built around placing search ads on the site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Google, which can already feel like an appendage to our brains, is now predicting what people are thinking before they even type.

articles.headline: Blair Memoir a Hit, Despite a Few Hard Knocks
articles.snippet: Some people may dislike the former prime minister, but that is not stopping record sales of his book.
articles.abstract: Some people may dislike the former prime minister, but that is not stopping record sales of his book.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  “You are my 10th prime minister,” Queen Elizabeth observes to Tony Blair when she meets him at Buckingham Palace on his first day in office in 1997, according to “A Journey: My Political Life,” Mr. Blair’s new memoir. “The first was Winston. That was before you were born.”

articles.headline: Union Accuses China of Illegal Clean Energy Subsidies
articles.snippet: The United Steelworkers union plans to file a legal case that accuses China of violating World Trade Organization rules.
articles.abstract: The United Steelworkers union plans to file a legal case that accuses China of violating World Trade Organization rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A broad trade case filed on Thursday by an American labor union, accusing China of unfairly subsidizing its clean energy industry, pressed a hot-button jobs issue in the United States during a Congressional election season.
